matched.actualTitle: Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI) in Registration Name Field - Environment Variable Disclosure
matched.matchReason: Both findings describe the same vulnerability: unsanitized user input from the registration name field is directly inserted into a Jinja2 template string without proper escaping or sandboxing. The actual finding provides more detailed evidence showing {{request.environ}} payload execution and environment variable disclosure (HOSTNAME, HOME, PATH, DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE, etc.), which demonstrates the SSTI vulnerability described in the expected finding. The location matches the file path specified in the expected finding, and the semantic details align perfectly - both describe template injection via unsanitized user input leading to remote code execution and information disclosure risks.

extra.title: No Brute Force Protection on Login Endpoint
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - The application lacks rate limiting, account lockout, or other brute force protection mechanisms on the login endpoint, allowing unlimited sequential login attempts without throttling or delays.

extra.title: Email Validation Bypass - Accepts Emails with Leading/Trailing Spaces
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Input validation weakness where the email field accepts and processes leading/trailing whitespace without normalization, potentially allowing duplicate account creation with whitespace variations.

extra.title: DEBUG Mode Enabled - Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - DEBUG=True exposes sensitive information through verbose error pages including URLconf configuration, internal module names, and Django framework details.

extra.title: Email Validation Bypass - Accepts Excessively Long Emails
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Server-side validation does not enforce the HTML maxlength='320' limit, allowing emails longer than RFC 5321 specifications (320 characters) to be accepted.

extra.title: Stored XSS in Step 3 via Name Parameter Injection
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - User-supplied name from Step 1 is reflected directly into JavaScript alert() statement without proper escaping, allowing arbitrary JavaScript execution through string breakout attacks.

extra.title: Insufficient Email Format Validation - Accepts Template Injection Payloads
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Email validation accepts invalid email formats containing template injection syntax like {{7*7}}@example.com and ${7*7}@example.com, violating RFC 5321/5322 standards.

extra.title: Weak Password Validation - Client-Side Only with Insufficient Minimum Length
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Password validation enforced only via HTML5 minlength='10' attribute on client-side, which can be bypassed through direct HTTP requests or client-side manipulation. 10 characters is below NIST recommendations.

extra.title: Workflow Manipulation - State Reversion via Step Revisit
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Multi-step registration workflow fails to enforce sequential completion; users can navigate backward to earlier steps and modify data, which persists through to later steps without workflow reset.

extra.title: Missing Duplicate Email Validation - Multiple Registrations with Same Email
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Email uniqueness constraint not enforced; users can register multiple accounts with identical email addresses, enabling account enumeration, bypass of email-based access controls, and registration abuse.

extra.title: Broken Authentication Mechanism on /accounts/login/ Endpoint
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Authentication system is completely non-functional; all login attempts result in HTTP 200 responses with login form redisplayed and no session establishment, indicating fundamental authentication failure.

extra.title: Potential IDOR Vulnerability in /accounts/preferences/ - User ID Parameter Accepted
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Endpoint accepts user_id parameters without authorization validation, demonstrating potential for horizontal privilege escalation once authentication is functional. Users could access/modify other users' preferences.

extra.title: Session Hijacking - Insufficient Session Validation
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Session validation fails to verify session ownership; attackers who obtain another user's session ID can directly access protected endpoints and assume that user's identity without additional authentication.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Logout Endpoint - GET Request Vulnerability
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - Logout endpoint accepts HTTP GET requests without CSRF token validation, allowing attackers to force logout via embedded requests in external websites or emails.

extra.title: Excessive CSRF Token Expiration - 1 Year Validity
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - CSRF tokens configured with 31,449,600 second (364-day) expiration far exceeds recommended maximum of 3,600-86,400 seconds (1 hour to 1 day), significantly extending attack window.

extra.title: Missing HttpOnly Flag on CSRF Token Cookie
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - CSRF token cookie lacks HttpOnly flag, making it accessible to JavaScript and vulnerable to exfiltration via XSS attacks, enabling XSS+CSRF compound attacks.

extra.title: Missing Secure Flag on CSRF Token Cookie
extra.assessment: Valid security discovery - CSRF token cookie lacks Secure flag, allowing transmission over unencrypted HTTP connections and making tokens vulnerable to man-in-the-middle interception.
